title: San Miguel (Chaparrastique)

quick_answer.what: San Miguel (locally known as Chaparrastique) is an active stratovolcano rising to 2,130 m (6,988 ft) in eastern El Salvador, one of the most active and prominent volcanoes in Central America.
quick_answer.status: Active — most recently erupted in November 2022–2023 (VEI 2). The volcano has erupted 45 times since its first recorded eruption in 1510, averaging one eruption roughly every 11 years.
quick_answer.famous_for: Its symmetrical cone dominating eastern El Salvador, its prolific lava flow history on the flanks during the 17th–19th centuries, and a dramatic VEI 3 explosion on December 29, 2013, that sent an ash column 9 km into the atmosphere.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — approximately 300,000 people live within 20 km of the summit, including the city of San Miguel (population ~250,000), El Salvador's third-largest city.

overview.content: San Miguel, known locally as Chaparrastique, is an active stratovolcano rising to 2,130 m (6,988 ft) in eastern El Salvador, making it one of the most prominent and one of the most active volcanoes in Central America. With 45 recorded eruptions since 1510 CE — an average of roughly one eruption every 11 years — San Miguel ranks among the most frequently erupting volcanoes along the entire Central American volcanic arc. The volcano's symmetrical cone dominates the landscape of eastern El Salvador and serves as a defining landmark for the city of San Miguel, El Salvador's third-largest city (population approximately 250,000), located just 11 km to the southeast. Approximately 300,000 people live within 20 km of the summit, making San Miguel one of the most population-exposed volcanoes in the Ring of Fire. The truncated summit is capped by a broad, deep crater complex that has been repeatedly modified by eruptions throughout the historical period. Tectonically, San Miguel sits on the Central American volcanic arc, generated by the subduction of the Cocos Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate along the Middle America Trench. The volcano's basaltic-andesitic composition and frequent activity reflect a prolific magma supply from the underlying subduction zone. Unlike many Central American volcanoes that produce primarily explosive eruptions, San Miguel has a notably mixed eruptive style: the historical record includes abundant flank lava flows (particularly during the 17th–19th centuries) alongside summit explosive eruptions and ash emissions that have dominated more recent activity.

geology_and_formation.content: San Miguel is part of the Central American volcanic arc, a 1,500-km chain of volcanoes extending from Guatemala to Panama, generated by the subduction of the Cocos Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate at approximately 7–8 cm per year. The volcano sits within the Salvadoran volcanic front, a particularly dense concentration of active volcanoes that includes Santa Ana (Ilamatepec), San Salvador, and Izalco. The San Miguel edifice is constructed primarily of andesitic and basaltic-andesitic lava flows and pyroclastic deposits, built over a basement of older volcanic and sedimentary rocks. The volcano rises from near sea level to its summit, with steep upper slopes giving way to more gently inclined lower flanks draped in extensive lava flow fields. The most prominent of these are the broad, sparsely vegetated lava fields on the southeastern flank, which represent accumulated flows from multiple historical eruptions during the 17th–19th centuries. These flows are so extensive that modern highways and a railroad have been built across them. The summit crater complex is broad and deep, reflecting centuries of explosive modification. Unlike many Central American volcanoes that feature well-defined single craters, San Miguel's summit has been repeatedly reshaped by eruptions, resulting in a complex, irregularly shaped depression. An important trend in the historical record is the upward migration of flank vent locations over time — earlier eruptions produced lava flows from vents low on the flanks, while more recent activity has been concentrated increasingly at the summit. The most recent eruptions (21st century) have consisted exclusively of minor ash emissions from the summit crater.

eruption_history_overview.content: San Miguel's 45 recorded eruptions since 1510 CE represent one of the most prolific eruptive histories of any volcano in Central America. The eruption record can be divided into three broad phases: an early colonial period (16th–17th centuries) characterized by flank lava flows and moderate explosive activity; a peak activity period (18th–19th centuries) with frequent flank eruptions producing the extensive lava fields on the eastern and southeastern slopes; and a modern period (20th–21st centuries) dominated by minor to moderate summit explosions and ash emissions. The maximum recorded VEI is 3, achieved during the December 2013 eruption — a relatively moderate ceiling compared to neighboring volcanoes like Santa Ana (VEI 3) and the historically devastating San Salvador volcano. However, the frequency of eruptions more than compensates for their relatively modest individual scale: San Miguel has erupted in some capacity in nearly every decade since 1850, and the 20th century alone saw at least 20 eruptive episodes. Historical eruption styles include effusive lava flows from flank vents (dominant in the 17th–19th centuries), Strombolian and Vulcanian explosions from the summit crater, and phreatic (steam-driven) eruptions. The transition from predominantly flank effusion to predominantly summit explosion over the historical period may reflect changes in the volcano's internal plumbing system, with flank vent pathways becoming sealed and magma increasingly reaching the surface only through the central conduit.

subsections.title: The December 2013 Eruption — Chaparrastique's Dramatic Reawakening (VEI 3)
subsections.content:
On December 29, 2013, San Miguel produced its most powerful eruption in recent history, a VEI 3 event that sent an ash and gas column approximately 9 km (5.6 mi) into the atmosphere. The explosion occurred from the summit crater and was preceded by only brief seismic precursors, catching authorities somewhat by surprise despite ongoing monitoring. The eruption column was visible across much of eastern El Salvador, and ashfall was reported in communities downwind.

Approximately 5,000 people were evacuated from communities closest to the volcano in the hours following the explosion. Although no direct fatalities occurred, the eruption caused agricultural damage from ashfall, temporary road closures, and significant public alarm. The 2013 event demonstrated that San Miguel remains capable of producing eruptions significantly larger than the minor ash puffs that had characterized its activity in the preceding decades, and it prompted a reassessment of hazard preparedness in the region.

subsections.title: 17th–19th Century Lava Flow Eruptions — Building the Flanks
subsections.content:
San Miguel's most voluminous historical eruptions occurred between the late 17th and late 19th centuries, when the volcano repeatedly produced lava flows from flank vents. Eruptions in 1699, 1762, 1769, 1787, 1819, 1844–1848, 1855, 1857, 1862, 1867–1868, 1882, and 1884 generated lava flows that extended down the northern, eastern, and southeastern flanks, many reaching several kilometers in length.

The southeastern flank flows are the most extensive, forming broad, dark lava fields that contrast sharply with the surrounding green agricultural land. These flows are so prominent and well-preserved that they remain a major landscape feature, with modern infrastructure — including the Pan-American Highway and a railroad — built across their surfaces. Individual flows from this period originated from vents at various elevations on the flanks, with eruptive fissures opening as low as 400 m elevation. The progressive migration of vent locations higher on the edifice over historical time suggests that the pathways for magma to reach the lower flanks have become increasingly obstructed.

subsections.title: The 2022–2023 Eruption — Most Recent Activity
subsections.content: San Miguel's most recent eruption began on November 15, 2022, with minor ash emissions from the summit crater. The activity, rated VEI 2, continued intermittently into 2023, consisting of Vulcanian explosions that produced ash plumes rising 1–3 km above the crater rim. This episode continued San Miguel's 21st-century pattern of relatively low-level explosive activity confined to the summit crater. MARN (El Salvador's environmental ministry) maintained elevated alert levels during the episode and restricted access to the upper slopes.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Following the 2022–2023 eruptive episode, San Miguel has returned to low-level background activity characterized by persistent degassing from the summit crater and occasional minor seismic events. The volcano is monitored continuously by MARN (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales), El Salvador's government agency responsible for environmental and geological hazards.

The monitoring network includes seismometers deployed around the volcano's flanks to detect volcanic earthquakes and tremor, webcams providing visual surveillance of the summit crater, and gas measurement instruments (particularly for sulfur dioxide). MARN maintains a color-coded alert system for San Miguel: green (normal), yellow (elevated activity), orange (approaching eruption), and red (eruption in progress). Given San Miguel's average eruption recurrence interval of approximately 11 years and its most recent activity in 2022–2023, the volcano is expected to erupt again within the coming decade.

The high population exposure — approximately 300,000 people within 20 km, including the city of San Miguel — makes effective monitoring and early warning critical. Emergency evacuation plans exist for communities closest to the volcano, though the challenges of evacuating a major urban area on short notice remain a significant concern.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content:
San Miguel presents a serious volcanic hazard to one of El Salvador's most densely populated regions. The primary threats include ashfall (the most frequent hazard, affecting agriculture, water supplies, transportation, and respiratory health across a wide area during summit eruptions), lava flows (historically the most voluminous hazard, though flank eruptions have not occurred since the 19th century; future flows could threaten communities and infrastructure on any flank), ballistic projectiles (volcanic bombs ejected during explosive eruptions, dangerous within several kilometers of the summit), pyroclastic flows (possible during larger eruptions, though not prominently recorded in San Miguel's historical activity), and lahars (volcanic mudflows generated by rainfall mobilizing fresh ash deposits on the steep upper slopes, channeled down river valleys toward populated areas).

The city of San Miguel, with approximately 250,000 inhabitants, lies just 11 km southeast of the summit — within the ashfall zone for even moderate eruptions and potentially within lahar hazard zones for larger events. The sparsely vegetated southeastern lava flow fields provide some buffer, but communities on the northern, eastern, and western flanks are more directly exposed.

El Salvador's volcanic hazard context is exceptionally challenging: the country has 16 Holocene volcanoes along a 250-km stretch, one of the highest volcanic densities in the world relative to land area, and its population of approximately 6.5 million people lives in close proximity to multiple active volcanic centers.

geography_and_physical_description.content:
San Miguel's symmetrical, truncated cone rises from near sea level to 2,130 m (6,988 ft), making it one of the tallest and most visually prominent peaks in eastern El Salvador. The upper slopes are steep and largely unvegetated, with exposed lava flows and pyroclastic deposits giving the summit area a barren, dark appearance. The broad summit crater complex — modified by centuries of eruptions — caps the cone with an irregularly shaped depression several hundred meters across.

The lower flanks display a striking contrast between different sectors. The southeastern and eastern flanks are dominated by extensive, dark lava flow fields from historical eruptions — broad expanses of solidified basaltic-andesitic lava that remain sparsely vegetated centuries after emplacement. These lava fields extend several kilometers from the summit and are crossed by major transportation routes including the Pan-American Highway. The northern and western flanks retain more vegetation, with coffee plantations and subsistence agriculture extending up the lower slopes.

The volcano rises from the broad coastal plain of eastern El Salvador, with the Pacific Ocean approximately 30 km to the south. The nearby volcanic neighbors include Chinameca to the east and the San Miguel volcanic field to the south. The city of San Miguel sprawls across the lowlands to the southeast, its urban footprint visible from the summit on clear days.

climate_and_global_impact.content:
San Miguel's eruptions have been exclusively regional in their atmospheric and climatic impact. The maximum recorded VEI of 3 (in 2013) produced an eruption column reaching approximately 9 km altitude — significant for local aviation and ashfall but far below the stratospheric injection threshold needed for measurable global climate effects. Even the most prolific lava flow eruptions of the 17th–19th centuries, while voluminous by San Miguel's standards, were modest on a global scale.

The volcano's primary atmospheric contribution is persistent degassing of sulfur dioxide and other volcanic gases from the summit crater. During periods of elevated activity, SO₂ plumes are detectable by satellite instruments and can affect air quality in downwind communities. Ashfall from eruptions can temporarily reduce visibility and air quality across eastern El Salvador, with impacts on aviation requiring coordination with the Washington VAAC (Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre).

cultural_significance.content: San Miguel volcano — known by its indigenous Nahuatl name Chaparrastique, meaning 'land of fertile fields' — is central to the cultural identity and landscape of eastern El Salvador. The volcano's symmetrical cone dominates the skyline of the city of San Miguel, the commercial capital of eastern El Salvador, and features prominently in the region's iconography, from municipal seals to tourist marketing. The name Chaparrastique reflects the volcano's dual nature: while capable of destruction, its volcanic soils have produced some of the most fertile agricultural land in El Salvador. Coffee cultivation on the lower slopes has been an economic mainstay since the 19th century, and the broader agricultural productivity of the volcanic plain supports the regional economy. This tension between volcanic hazard and volcanic benefit is a defining feature of life in eastern El Salvador. The volcano also holds significance in El Salvador's colonial history. Spanish chroniclers documented eruptions as early as 1510, and the evolving city of San Miguel — founded in 1530 — has coexisted with the volcano for nearly five centuries. The relationship between the city and its volcanic neighbor mirrors that of many Latin American urban centers built in the shadow of active volcanoes, from Popocatépetl above Mexico City to Cotopaxi near Quito.

visiting_and_tourism.content:
San Miguel volcano can be hiked during periods of low volcanic activity, though access to the summit depends on the alert level maintained by MARN. The ascent typically takes 4–6 hours and passes through agricultural land on the lower slopes before reaching the barren volcanic terrain of the upper cone. The summit crater offers dramatic views, though visitors should be aware that volcanic gases (particularly SO₂) can concentrate in and around the crater.

Local guides are available in the town of San Jorge, on the northern flank, and are strongly recommended. The hike is strenuous, with steep, loose volcanic terrain on the upper slopes. Visitors should carry adequate water, sun protection, and warm layers for the summit (which can be significantly cooler than the tropical lowlands). The best months for climbing are November through April (the dry season).

The city of San Miguel, 11 km southeast, serves as the primary base for volcano visits. It is connected to San Salvador by the Pan-American Highway (approximately 140 km east) and has hotels, restaurants, and transportation services. The nearby Jiquilisco Bay mangrove ecosystem and the colonial town of Alegría offer additional attractions in the region.

nearby_volcanoes.content: San Miguel sits within the densely volcanic landscape of El Salvador, which packs 16 Holocene volcanoes into a country smaller than New Jersey. The nearest volcanic neighbors include Chinameca immediately to the east and the San Miguel volcanic field to the south. To the west along the Salvadoran volcanic front lie San Vicente (Chichontepec), San Salvador, and Santa Ana (Ilamatepec) — the latter being El Salvador's highest volcano at 2,381 m. Izalco, the 'Lighthouse of the Pacific,' was Central America's most active volcano during the 19th and early 20th centuries. This concentration of volcanic hazards makes El Salvador one of the most volcanically exposed nations on Earth.

etymology.content: The volcano's official name, San Miguel, derives from the nearby city of San Miguel, itself named after the Archangel Michael by Spanish colonizers upon its founding in 1530. The indigenous Nahuatl name, Chaparrastique (sometimes spelled Chaparrastik), translates approximately to 'land of fertile fields' or 'place of good soil,' reflecting the agricultural productivity of the volcano's surrounding lowlands. Both names remain in active use, with 'Chaparrastique' being more common in local and informal contexts.

facts: San Miguel has erupted 45 times since 1510 CE, making it one of the most frequently erupting volcanoes in Central America — averaging roughly one eruption every 11 years.
The volcano's extensive southeastern lava flow fields are so large that the Pan-American Highway and a railroad were built across their surfaces.
Approximately 300,000 people live within 20 km of San Miguel's summit, including El Salvador's third-largest city (population ~250,000) located just 11 km away.
Historical flank vent locations have progressively migrated higher on the edifice over five centuries, with 21st-century activity confined entirely to the summit crater.
The December 2013 VEI 3 eruption produced an ash column reaching 9 km into the atmosphere, the most powerful explosion at San Miguel in at least several decades.
San Miguel is known locally as Chaparrastique, a Nahuatl name meaning 'land of fertile fields' — reflecting the agricultural productivity of its volcanic soils.
El Salvador packs 16 Holocene volcanoes into a country of just 21,041 km² — one of the highest volcanic densities on Earth relative to land area.
The 1844–1848 eruption lasted four years, producing lava flows from multiple flank vents that contributed to the extensive lava fields still visible today.
In the 19th century alone, San Miguel erupted at least 14 times — roughly once every seven years.
The broad, deep summit crater complex has been modified by virtually every historical eruption, making it one of the most actively evolving volcanic craters in Central America.
Coffee cultivation on San Miguel's lower slopes has been a major economic activity since the 19th century, thriving on the rich volcanic soils but vulnerable to ashfall during eruptions.
San Miguel's VEI has never exceeded 3 in the historical record, but its eruption frequency and proximity to a major city make it a persistent and serious hazard.

faqs.question: Is San Miguel volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, San Miguel (Chaparrastique) is one of the most active volcanoes in Central America. It most recently erupted in November 2022 through 2023, with ash emissions from the summit crater. The volcano has produced 45 recorded eruptions since 1510 CE, averaging roughly one eruption every 11 years. San Miguel is continuously monitored by MARN (El Salvador's environmental ministry), which maintains seismometers, webcams, and gas sensors around the volcano. Given its eruption frequency, another eruption is expected within the coming decade.

faqs.question: When did San Miguel last erupt?
faqs.answer: San Miguel's most recent eruption began on November 15, 2022, with ash emissions from the summit crater. The activity, rated VEI 2, continued intermittently into 2023 with Vulcanian explosions producing ash plumes. Prior to this, the most significant recent eruption was on December 29, 2013, when a VEI 3 explosion generated an ash column approximately 9 km (5.6 mi) high, forcing the evacuation of approximately 5,000 people from nearby communities.

faqs.question: How tall is San Miguel volcano?
faqs.answer: San Miguel rises to 2,130 m (6,988 ft) above sea level, making it one of the tallest volcanoes in eastern El Salvador. The volcano rises from near sea level, giving it significant visual prominence across the eastern Salvadoran landscape. By comparison, Santa Ana (Ilamatepec), the tallest volcano in El Salvador, reaches 2,381 m. San Miguel's summit is capped by a broad, deep crater complex that has been repeatedly modified by its frequent eruptions.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is San Miguel?
faqs.answer: San Miguel is a stratovolcano (composite volcano) built from alternating layers of andesitic to basaltic-andesitic lava flows and explosive pyroclastic deposits. Its eruption style is notably mixed: the 17th–19th centuries were characterized by frequent lava flow eruptions from flank vents that built the extensive lava fields on the southeastern slopes, while 20th–21st century activity has been dominated by summit explosions and ash emissions. This dual eruptive character makes San Miguel somewhat unusual among Central American stratovolcanoes.

faqs.question: Is San Miguel dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes, San Miguel poses significant volcanic hazards. Approximately 300,000 people live within 20 km of the summit, including the city of San Miguel (population ~250,000), located just 11 km to the southeast. The primary hazards are ashfall (the most frequent), lava flows (historically voluminous though less common recently), lahars (volcanic mudflows during rainy season), and explosive eruptions that could produce pyroclastic flows. The volcano's high eruption frequency — averaging one event every 11 years — means that the population is repeatedly exposed to volcanic hazards.

faqs.question: Can you climb San Miguel volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, San Miguel can be hiked during periods of low volcanic activity, though summit access depends on the alert level set by MARN. The ascent typically takes 4–6 hours from the lower slopes and passes through coffee plantations before reaching barren volcanic terrain. Local guides are available from San Jorge on the northern flank and are strongly recommended. Visitors should carry water, sun protection, and warm layers. The summit crater may contain volcanic gases, so caution is essential. The best season for climbing is November through April (dry season). Always check current volcanic conditions before attempting the hike.

faqs.question: How does San Miguel compare to other Salvadoran volcanoes?
faqs.answer: San Miguel is one of the most active volcanoes in El Salvador, with 45 recorded eruptions — more than any other Salvadoran volcano except Izalco (52 eruptions). However, San Miguel's eruptions have generally been smaller (maximum VEI 3) than the most powerful events at other Salvadoran volcanoes. Its main distinction is its proximity to a major population center: the city of San Miguel (population ~250,000) is just 11 km away. El Salvador has 16 Holocene volcanoes in a country of only 21,041 km², making it one of the most volcanically dense nations on Earth.

faqs.question: What happened during the 2013 eruption?
faqs.answer: On December 29, 2013, San Miguel (Chaparrastique) produced a VEI 3 eruption — its most powerful in recent decades. The explosion from the summit crater generated an ash and gas column that rose approximately 9 km (5.6 mi) into the atmosphere, visible across much of eastern El Salvador. Ashfall was reported in downwind communities, and approximately 5,000 people were evacuated from the closest settlements. No direct fatalities occurred, but the eruption caused agricultural damage and significant public alarm. The event demonstrated that San Miguel remains capable of producing eruptions beyond the minor ash emissions that had characterized its recent activity.
